description.value: Painted wooden shabti of Merenset with a black lappet-wig, a yellow modelled face with black and white eyes and a red mouth and a yellow, green and red collar that envelopes the parallel yellow hands; the front of the leg section is inscribed with a column of black painted Hieroglyphs upon a yellow ground outlined in black; the body is white and the back is decorated with a representation of a yellow seed-basket and two red hoes.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Wooden shabti of Merenset: the body is painted white, suggesting the brilliant linen shroud that was appropriate to the dead. Over this is a large collar, coloured blue, green, red and yellow. The arms are crossed and the hands are shown protruding through the lower rows of the collar—a graphic peculiarity which also appears on mummiform coffins in the 19th and 20th Dynasties. The painter seems to have decided not to try to superimpose agricultural tools on the polychrome collar, where perhaps they would have lacked clarity. Instead, he left the hands empty and painted the two hoes on the back of the figure, where they appear "floating" rather incongruously on each side of a large yellow grain basket hanging on cords. The design of the figure was completed by a single line of inscription on the front, introducing the name of the owner as 'sehedj' and adding the opening words of the shabti spell without detailing any of the specific tasks that the figure was required to perform.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Varnished polychrome wooden shabti: a replica of the mummy, but its coloration, with yellow inscriptions on a black background, is taken from that of contemporary coffins and other funerary objects, a pattern of colouring which became fashionable in the reign of Tuthmosis III. The face is a reddish colour and the entire surface of the figure has been liberally coated with a thick yellow varnish. Although the object can only be a shabti, it has neither the agricultural tools nor the appropriate spell from the 'Book of the Dead'. The inscription is simply the age-old 'hetep-di-nesu' formula.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum

description.value: Green glazed composition shabti of Psamtek born of Tawahbast with a lappet-wig, a modelled face with a beard, crossed hands in relief holding an incised adze and a hoe, the front of the leg section is inscribed with a column of incised hieroglyphs, the top of the back-pillar is similarly inscribed, there is a plinth beneath the feet.

legal.credit_line: © The Trustees of the British Museum
